title: Vesting Could Transfer Tokens to the Original Gnosis Safe
content:
**Update**
Marked as "Acknowledged" by the client. The client provided the following explanation:

> The entities will have separate safe addresses on mainnet

![Image 66: Alert icon](https://certificate.quantstamp.com/full/sapien/ffb7e698-6178-46f0-8df8-52e537af70c0/static/media/info-icon-alert.3c9578483b1cf3181c9bfb6fec7dc641.svg)

**Update**
Marked as "Acknowledged" by the client. The client provided the following explanation:

> This suggestion didn't involve immediate action but it has been noted for the deployment process.

![Image 67: Alert icon](https://certificate.quantstamp.com/full/sapien/ffb7e698-6178-46f0-8df8-52e537af70c0/static/media/info-icon-alert.3c9578483b1cf3181c9bfb6fec7dc641.svg)

**Update**
Marked as "Acknowledged" by the client. The client provided the following explanation:

> This suggestion didn't involve immediate action but it has been noted for the deployment process.

**Description:** The `releaseTokens()` function transfers the tokens from the `gnosisSafe` (who originally got all the token supply) to the `schedule.safe` address which originally was set as the same `gnosisSafe`. This could lead to the contract and the original receiving team thinking that a vesting was succesfully released when the original owner of the token still has them.

**Recommendation:** Avoid minting the tokens beforehand and only mint when it is needed.
